newsitem.title: USA: U.S. crop progress highlights - USDA.
newsitem.headline: U.S. crop progress highlights - USDA.

text.p: The U.S. Agriculture Department Monday said 14 percent of the U.S. winter wheat crop was harvested compared with 27 percent a year ago and the five-year average of 22 percent.

In the report on conditions for the week ended June 22, USDA said two percent of the U.S. winter wheat crop was in very poor condition, seven percent poor, 24 percent fair, 55 percent good and 12 percent excellent.
The department said one percent of the U.S. corn crop was in very poor condition, six percent poor, 26 percent fair, 55 percent good and 12 percent excellent.
The department said two percent of the U.S. corn crop was silking, compared with three percent a year ago and three percent for the five year average.
It said two percent of the U.S. soybean crop was in very poor condition, seven percent poor, 30 percent fair, 53 percent good and eight percent excellent.
The department reported four percent of the U.S. cotton crop was in very poor condition, 10 percent poor, 32 percent fair, 45 percent good and nine percent excellent.

USDA said six percent of the U.S. spring wheat crop was headed compared with two percent a year ago and the five-year average of 15 percent. Fifty-two percent of the crop was in good-to-excellent condition compared with 86 percent a year ago, the department said.
